The Buddha's instructions for the mendic: The Buddha wishes to go on retreat for three months
No one should approach him, except for the one who brings his almsfood
The mendicants agree to the Buddha's instructions
The Buddha's meditation during the rainy: Mindful, I breathe in. Mindful, I breathe out.
When breathing in heavily, I know: ‘I’m breathing in heavily.’ When breathing out heavily, I know: ‘I’m breathing out heavily.’
When breathing in lightly, I know: ‘I’m breathing in lightly.’ When breathing out lightly, I know: ‘I’m breathing out lightly.’
I know: ‘I’ll breathe in experiencing the whole body.’
I know: ‘I’ll breathe in calming the bodily process.’
I know: ‘I’ll breathe in experiencing rapture.’
I know: ‘I’ll breathe in experiencing pleasure.’
I know: ‘I’ll breathe in experiencing the whole mind.’
I know: ‘I’ll breathe in calming the mental process.’
I know: ‘I’ll breathe in experiencing immersion.’
I know: ‘I’ll breathe in observing letting go.’
I know: ‘I’ll breathe out observing letting go.’
The benefits of immersion due to mindful: The development and cultivation of immersion due to mindfulness of breathing leads to the ending of defilements for trainee mendicants.
The development and cultivation of immersion due to mindfulness of breathing leads to blissful meditation in the present life, and to mindfulness and awareness for perfected mendicants.
